content.title: Hypergraph Structure
content.summary: A hypergraph consists of a set of hyperedges, where each edge is a finite set of vertices. Unlike regular graphs where edges connect exactly 2 vertices, hyperedges can contain any number of vertices.
content.details: The definition uses `Set (Finset V)` to represent the edge set, allowing infinite hypergraphs while keeping each edge finite.

content.title: k-Uniform Hypergraph
content.summary: A hypergraph is k-uniform if every hyperedge contains exactly k vertices. For k=2, this gives ordinary graphs. For k=3, every edge is a triple of vertices.
content.details: 3-uniform hypergraphs are a central object in extremal combinatorics, generalizing the study of graphs to higher-dimensional structures.

content.title: Transversal Definition
content.summary: A transversal (also called vertex cover or hitting set) is a set of vertices that intersects every hyperedge. Every hypergraph has at least one transversal (the entire vertex set).
content.details: Finding minimum transversals is NP-hard in general, but critical hypergraphs have special structure that constrains this problem.

content.title: Transversal-Criticality
content.summary: A hypergraph is k-transversal-critical if its transversal number is exactly k, AND removing any edge reduces the transversal number. This captures the notion that every edge is 'essential' for requiring a cover of size k.
content.details: The conjunction of τ(H) = k and criticality for every edge is a strong constraint that limits the possible structure of such hypergraphs.

content.title: Proper Coloring
content.summary: A proper coloring of a hypergraph assigns colors to vertices such that no edge is monochromatic (all vertices the same color). This generalizes graph coloring to hypergraphs.
content.details: For 2-uniform hypergraphs (graphs), this reduces to standard graph coloring. For k-uniform hypergraphs with k > 2, the constraint is weaker since edges have more vertices.

content.title: Chromatic-Criticality
content.summary: A hypergraph is k-chromatic-critical if its chromatic number is exactly k, AND removing any edge reduces the chromatic number. This is the coloring analogue of transversal-criticality.
content.details: Chromatic-critical graphs and hypergraphs have been extensively studied. Unlike transversal-criticality, chromatic-criticality allows for high minimum degree constructions.

content.title: The Transversal Question
content.summary: Formalizes the transversal interpretation: Does there exist a 3-uniform hypergraph with τ(H) = 3, transversal-critical, and minimum degree ≥ 7?
content.details: This existential statement will be proven FALSE using Li's bound theorem.

content.title: The Chromatic Question
content.summary: Formalizes the chromatic interpretation: Does there exist a 3-uniform hypergraph with χ(H) = 3, chromatic-critical, and minimum degree ≥ 7?
content.details: This existential statement will be proven TRUE using Lovász's construction.

content.title: Li's Bound Axiom
content.summary: Li (2025) proved that every 3-transversal-critical 3-uniform hypergraph has a vertex of degree at most 6. This is stated as an axiom encoding the mathematical result.
content.details: The full proof involves careful analysis of how edges must be distributed to maintain criticality while ensuring τ = 3. The bound 6 is tight.

content.title: Transversal Answer: NO
content.summary: Using Li's bound, we prove that no 3-transversal-critical 3-uniform hypergraph can have minimum degree ≥ 7. The proof is by contradiction.
content.details: The proof structure: assume such a hypergraph exists, apply Li's bound to get min degree ≤ 6, contradict the assumption min degree ≥ 7.

content.title: Lovász Construction Axiom
content.summary: Lovász showed that for any d, there exist 3-chromatic-critical 3-uniform hypergraphs with minimum degree at least d. This gives infinitely many positive examples.
content.details: The construction is non-trivial and involves carefully building hypergraphs where every edge is essential for maintaining χ = 3.

content.title: Chromatic Answer: YES
content.summary: Using Lovász's construction with d = 7, we obtain a 3-chromatic-critical 3-uniform hypergraph with minimum degree ≥ 7.
content.details: The proof simply instantiates the existence axiom with d = 7 to get the required hypergraph.

content.title: Complete Resolution
content.summary: The main theorem combining both answers: the transversal question is FALSE and the chromatic question is TRUE. This completely resolves Erdős Problem #834 for both interpretations.
content.details: The resolution demonstrates how the same informal question can have different formal answers depending on interpretation.

content.title: Tightness of Bound
content.summary: The bound 6 in Li's theorem is tight: there exist 3-transversal-critical 3-uniform hypergraphs achieving minimum degree exactly 6.
content.details: This shows the bound cannot be improved, making Li's result optimal.

content.title: Summary Theorem
content.summary: Combines all results: Li's bound holds universally for transversal-critical hypergraphs, and Lovász's construction provides chromatic-critical hypergraphs with arbitrarily high minimum degree.
content.details: This theorem serves as a comprehensive summary of all the key mathematical results in the formalization.
